perturbation.original_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within fifteen (15) days following Newegg's written notice of the breach.
perturbation.changed_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within five (5) days following Newegg's written notice of the breach.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to five days may be considered unreasonable, especially considering the complexity of the obligations outlined in the agreement, potentially violating California's implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: California law implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. The implied covenant prevents either contracting party from unfairly frustrating the other party's right to receive the benefits of the agreement. Reducing the cure period to five days, especially in a complex sponsorship agreement, could be seen as a violation of this covenant if it doesn't allow the breaching party a reasonable opportunity to remedy the breach. This is subjective, but a court might find that five days is not a reasonable time to cure in this context.

perturbation.original_text: Before any Party (the "Complaining Party") may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the "Non Complaining Party"), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party's complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least thirty (30) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.changed_text: Before any Party (the "Complaining Party") may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the "Non Complaining Party"), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party's complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least seven (7) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the mandatory negotiation period before initiating legal proceedings to seven days could be deemed insufficient under California law, potentially conflicting with the principle of promoting alternative dispute resolution and good faith negotiation.
perturbation.law_explanation: While not directly mandating a specific timeframe, California Code of Civil Procedure § 1281 favors arbitration and alternative dispute resolution. By reducing the negotiation period to seven days, the modified clause may be viewed as undermining the spirit of encouraging parties to genuinely attempt resolution before resorting to litigation, potentially contradicting this broader policy promoting ADR.

perturbation.original_text: If posted, the notice shall be deemed to have been received five (5) working days after the date of posting or, in the case of a notice to an addressee not in the country of the sender, ten (10) working days after the date of posting.
perturbation.changed_text: If posted, the notice shall be deemed to have been received one (1) working day after the date of posting or, in the case of a notice to an addressee not in the country of the sender, three (3) working days after the date of posting.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the deemed receipt time for mailed notices to one (1) working day (or 3 days if international) is unreasonable and contradicts standard legal practices for providing sufficient notice, especially given potential mail delays. This could violate due process if critical deadlines are missed because of this clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
perturbation.law_explanation: The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment requires fair notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard. While this primarily applies to government actions, a contractual provision that unreasonably shortens the notice period, making it difficult for a party to respond to legal notices or other critical communications, could be challenged as a violation of public policy, particularly if it leads to a deprivation of property or other significant rights. One (1) working day for domestic and three (3) working days for international mail are likely insufficient for reliable receipt and processing of important notices, therefore contradicting principles of Due Process by effectively hindering a party's ability to adequately prepare a response.
